question.title: What may hold back from running the simplest Java code in Intellij?
question.body:
I wanted to take (almost the first) steps towards Java and IntelliJ Idea, installed JDK (21.0.7 community editon) and IntelliJ IDEA 2025.1 (Community Edition) on my Ubuntu. Started the IntelliJ and discovered there is tutorial IdeaLearningProject and took it for introduction. Step 6 in this tutorial is running the current file

As you may see from the screenshot:

  1. the run-button is inactive
  2. the tooltip says "The file in the editor is not runnable"
  3. neither does help the shortcut.

After googleing the "not runnable"-tip and trying different solutions (which did not help, but closely furter below) I thought to create first sample project with simplest code to test, does this run?

So I created New -> Project and ticked the option "add sample code". Without changing anything I clicked the run-button which:

  1. deactiveted the buttton (as in tutorial)
  2. outed some error:

Error running 'Main' com.android.tools.idea.gradle.dcl.lang.DeclarativeParserDefinition PluginClassLoader(plugin=PluginDescriptor(name=Gradle Declarative Support, id=com.android.tools.gradle.dcl, descriptorPath=plugin.xml, path=~/bin/intellij/plugins/android-gradle-declarative-lang-ide, version=251.23774.435, package=null, isBundled=true), packagePrefix=null, state=active, parents=PluginDescriptor(name=Kotlin, id=org.jetbrains.kotlin, descriptorPath=plugin.xml, path=~/bin/intellij/plugins/Kotlin, version=251.23774.435-IJ, package=org.jetbrains.kotlin, isBundled=true), PluginDescriptor(name=Gradle, id=com.intellij.gradle, descriptorPath=plugin.xml, path=~/bin/intellij/plugins/gradle, version=251.23774.435, package=null, isBundled=true), PluginDescriptor(name=Java, id=com.intellij.java, descriptorPath=plugin.xml, path=~/bin/intellij/plugins/java, version=251.23774.435, package=null, isBundled=true), )

This error does not make any sense to me.

So what have I tried? After googleing some suggestions were:

  1. mark directory as "Sources Root". tried, it was already. unmarked and marked again. nothing changed
  2. restore IDE default settings. Did, restarted, nothing changed.
  3. "It looks like you have not added a run configuration"-answer in SO https://stackoverflow.com/a/78779175/196241 notices " I tried to add some, but I have no clue, what this conf should contain. I tried some examples provided there, but nothing worked. So I created project with sample code, but this did not include also any run configuration. Should it?

The sample Main class looks like this:

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.printf("Hello and welcome!");

        for (int i = 1; i <= 5; i++) {
            System.out.println("i = " + i);
        }
    }
}

If I try to run it, it directs me to edit configuration, from the selection the "Applications" seems the only viable of options, but after choosing it and running I get warning:

Configuration is still incorrect. Do you want to edit it again?

If I opt to continue, I get error:

Error running 'Unnamed' No main class defined

My problem seems to be bind to some kind of configuration file (for build system?), but why is this missing? How should I know what is missing, already in tutorial-phase?

I'd like to find the answer in IntelliJ-context, swapping to other IDE is next path, if needed. As you already assumed, yes, I am totally stranger to Java ecosystem.

answers.body:
tl;dr

  • Use latest IntelliJ, preferably installed automatically via the JetBrains Toolbox app.
  • Let IntelliJ download a JDK for you.
  • Ask IntelliJ to create a new project for you, to be managed by Maven.
  • Click the green triangle shown in the gutter next to your main method.

Alternatively, you skip the IDE altogether, and just use command-line.

Details

Getting started with Java can be frustrating, as can learning a new IDE like IntelliJ. But both Java and IntelliJ are amazingly powerful and flexible technologies, and fun too, once you get past the speed bumps when starting out.

I cannot tell from your description exactly where things went off the rails. So here are some instructions to try again.

First be sure you have installed the latest version of IntelliJ.

JetBrains Toolbox app

Tip: I highly recommend uninstalling if you installed IntelliJ manually. Then install JetBrains Toolbox app. That app installs a mini-menu that makes it much easier to install and upgrade versions of IntelliJ (and all the other products published by JetBrains).

When you have the latest IntelliJ installed, then choose File > New Project. Use the first item in list Java. Try to make your dialog look something like this.

Name can be anything you want. This will be the name of the folder containing all your project files.

Location can be any folder you want. Generally best to have a single place where you keep all your project folders.

Create Git repository can be turned off, unchecked. Git as an advanced tool for remembering snapshots of your project over time. Not needed when just learning, or playing around.

Build System

Build System (see Wikipedia) refers to a tool to help you with all the other tools needed to compile your code, obtain needed libraries (“dependencies”), track assets such as images, and package it all together into a final software artifact such as a JAR file or a double-clickable (executable) app.

In the old days, every IDE used their own proprietary build system. This created frustrating vendor lock-in. So people invented build systems defined outside any one particular IDE, with Apache Ant being one of the first in the Java ecosystem.

Nowadays most Java developers use either Apache Maven or Gradle as their build tools. Of those two, I suggest Maven as it is a bit simpler to get started with, however both are excellent tools. You seem to have chosen Gradle on your first attempt, but I suggest you try again with Maven. Notice that Maven option in screenshot above.

Maven and Gradle are both supported by all the major IDEs: IntelliJ, Eclipse, and NetBeans. Maven and Gradle both work the very same way regardless of which IDE you happen to be using. You can easily move your Maven-driven or Gradle-driven project from one IDE to another. And your Maven-driven or Gradle-driven project can be shared with other programmers without regard for what IDE they happen to be using.

JDK

A JDK is an implementation of the Java specifications, along with developer tooling.

Several vendors provide JDK products, though not all license the Java™ moniker from the trademark owner Oracle Corp. These vendors include Amazon, BellSoft, Azul Systems, Microsoft, SAP, IBM, Red Hat, Oracle, Adoptium of the Eclipse Foundation, and more. All of these provide excellent products, thoroughly tested. Most of the products are based mostly, if not entirely, on the OpenJDK source code project.

In our screenshot above, notice the JDK pop-up menu. From there you can choose a JDK you have already installed. Or choose the menu item asking IntelliJ to download a JDK from one of the subset of vendors listed above. If you have no particular vendor in mind, then I suggest choosing Eclipse Temurin from Adoptium of the Eclipse Foundation.

Version 24 of Java is current. Versions 8, 11, 17, 21, and likely 25 are long-term support versions.

Advanced Settings

These settings are specific to Maven.

GroupId will be the package name used to organize the Java files you write. The convention is to reverse the domain name of your company’s URL, with your app name, such as com.acme.powerapp. If you have no domain name registered, just invent up to get going.

ArtifactId will be used in naming your final artifact. In this case, that artifact is JAR file.

Code editor

When you click Create to make your project, you should see a window like one below, with a list of created project files listed on the left.

Double-click Main to see the file that makes up the core of your Java app. There you will find a method named exactly main. By default, the JVM looks for this method when starting to run your app.

Run your app

Notice the hollow green triangle in the gutter of the code editor, the one next to that main method we mentioned above. 👉🏽 To run your project, just click that green triangle. As your app executes, find its output in the Run pane at the bottom of the window shown above.

Sans IDE, just command-line

To just get started, you can skip the IDE altogether, no IntelliJ.

Just install a JDK. Without IntelliJ, I suggest using the command-line tool SDKMAN! to quite easily locate, download, install, and uninstall a JDK on Linux, macOS, etc. Any version of Java 11 or later will work for this exercise.

Use any text-editor to create a file such as this. The name of the file should match the name you declare for your class.

Given this particular example, the containing file would be named exactly HelloWorldApp.java.

class HelloWorldApp 
{
    public static void main(String[] args) 
    {
        System.out.println( "Hello World!" );
    }
}

Pass the path to that .java file to the java executable found in the bin folder of your installed JDK. Something like this:

java /Users/basil_dot_work/HelloWorldApp.java

You should then see this appear on your console:

Hello World!

Spice it up with the current time, and run again.

class HelloWorldApp {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.println( "Hello World! " + java.time.ZonedDateTime.now() );
    }
}

Hello World! 2025-04-22T18:44:43.288814-07:00[America/Los_Angeles]

What is actually happening here is:

  1. The java program recognizes that a .java file is source code, and needs to be compiled. So the java utility calls upon the javac program to actually compile.
  2. The javac program compiles your .java file’s source code into a class. That class is cached in memory.
  3. The java program you originally executed then takes over again, to execute the main method found in the cached class.

For all the gory details, see JEP 330: Launch Single-File Source-Code Programs. And future versions of Java will enable a new student to write even less code for a simpler Hello World experience, per JEP 495.

See specifications for java & javac programs at the JDK 24 documentation website.

More info

For more info, see The Java Tutorials provided free of cost by Oracle Corp, such as this page.

I also recommend the book Head First Java, 3rd Edition by Kathy Sierra, Bert Bates, Trisha Gee.

Have fun.

I just opened IntelliJ community, created a Java project, and asked it to add sample code.

As you can see from the screen shot, there's a green arrow in the gutter that lets me run the Main class.

You can also see the output in the console at the bottom.

This took me less than a minute.

IntelliJ works.

question_comments.body: @Sweeper removed IntelliJ and installed again. And it works. Thank you!
it should show you a selection of classes which contains a runnable main method. Choose the one you would like to run
@pebbleunit I am confused, what should I select then?
The first error message seems to suggest that one of your plugins is broken. Did you try reinstalling IntelliJ?

When you go to edit configuration and select Applications, it should show in Build and run the configurations for how to call your class. Typically this will be empty, then you can select a java source, optionally a module (if you are using one), and select a Main class. If you just run it without selecting anything, the java -cp [main class] call will be invalid
@Sweeper Clicking on this button (Run with Profiler) says "Nothing here". Build system is by default IntelliJ and I did not change it.
Also, what build system have you selected when creating a new project? Maven, gradle, or IntelliJ?
Is there a green play button in the gutter, next to the main method? What happens when you click that?

79587659.body: @w.k FYI, using the JetBrains Toolbox can automatically update you to the latest version of IntelliJ, and let you rollback to an earlier version if ever there is a problem. You can also access the early access program through JetBrains Toolbox if you so desire.
Thank you for such a thorough explanation, I got quite a few new details. My problem solved after removing IntelliJ and installing it again.
@duffymo Thanks for the comment. It inspired me to show the plain command-line execution as well. Between us, I think we covered all a beginner needs.

See my answer below.   No dependencies, no need for Maven.   The Java compiler is sufficient.   Future ready?   They can't run Hello World.   Let's focus on that.  I love Maven, but it's not needed here.

@duffymo I agree on keeping it as simple as possible. But in this case, where already using IntelliJ, creating the Maven project adds no more complexity than using IntelliJ's native build system. See my finalized instructions -> Nothing Maven specific at all. However, the user is now future-ready to do further work which eventually will make handy use of Maven to install dependencies, manage packaging into an artifact, etc.

No need for Maven to run what amounts to Hello, World.   I think it makes this unnecessarily complex.   It's possible to run a simple class with a main method in IntelliJ without Maven or Gradle.   Compile and run.
